ironic_python_agent/hardware.py.message: I'm wondering if actually doing string evaluation in the list is really the best thing which makes me think Arne's fix is the direction we want to go.

This is very close to a solution I was looking for but didn't see, hence my patch in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675857.

While your proposal is clearly more elegant than mine, there is a special case which this if statement does not cover I think: empty md devices after a disk failure in a RAID-0. In such a scenario (which we ran into in production), the IPA will detect an md device, but mark the remaining drive as spare (and the device as empty with type  'md'). Since we ask for block_type 'raid' in delete_configuration, the healthy disk will not be cleaned and cause problems upon create_configuration.

Maybe a

"or (devtype='md' and 0 == device.get('SIZE'))"

would fix this?

ironic/conductor/utils.py.message:
shouldn't this be always False ?
My understanding is that cleaning_error_handler is called every time there is a failure in the cleaning process, so the node should never be powered off when reaching this point.

There are situations where this function is called and the node should probably be shut off (like when the interfaces are validated to see if cleaning is feasible).

I decided to keep the current function behavior as the default since everyone was fine with this during the past years (a kind of behavioral backwards compatibility), so I only changed the calls where this seemed obviously wrong to me.

My concern is that this could be a bit confusing as the node will end up in CLEANFAIL, but powered off or on based on what triggered the call, and might not be always clear.
For example, the case you mentioned, when the interfaces are validated, will (or should) bring the node in CLEANFAIL and then it powers it off.
It still goes against the idea of being in maintenance and powered on if the cleaning fails, or in this case the validation, which being a prerequisite for the cleaning, should still be investigated.
With that said, I understand the need of keeping backwards compatibility, so if everyone else is ok with that, I am too :)

lib/nova.message:
This is a nit but frickler brought up a decent point in IRC that nova-compute will be using a cache local to the host on the subnode and arguably should be pointing at the cache on the controller. I don't really know how much nova-compute actually leverages a cache if enabled though, and nova-compute for the most part should avoid hitting things (resources) managed by the controller.

So I don't think it hurts to enable the cache on subnodes, but it's likely also not necessary.

What you could do though is move the cache enablement logic for nova to this conditional and then we don't configure the cache on subnodes. The nova-compute service on the controller would still have the cache enabled, but like I said I'm not sure it really matters.

If we want to be strict about not using the cache in nova-compute, we have to make sure to remove the cache config from NOVA_CPU_CONF which is a bit more clunky IMO.
This comment could have been updated a bit but it's OK.
nit: could mention why this is done here rather than in general, i.e. since we will re-use the cache on the controller and not configure it for subnode n-cpu which doesn't probably need it anyway.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/openstack/co.message: I would prefer to fix this rather than ignore it.

The documentation for eventlet.pools.pool recommends this usage:
"
    Pool class implements resource limitation and construction.
    There are two ways of using Pool: passing a `create` argument or subclassing. In either case you must provide a way to create the resource.
    When using `create` argument, pass a function with no arguments::
    http_pool = pools.Pool(create=httplib2.Http)
"
and the create function docstring:
"Generate a new pool item.  In order for the pool to
function, either this method must be overriden in a subclass or the pool must be constructed with the `create` argument. It accepts no arguments and returns a single instance of whatever thing the pool is supposed to contain.
"
It does also mention another solution: passing the create function at initialization. I'm not sure how difficult it would be to implement that usage, but I could look into it.
OK - since this is one of the recommended ways to use this and we're (hopefully) going to get rid of this code in favour of oslo_messaging at some point, just stick with ignoring the warning.
This seems like a bug. Maybe we need a launchpad raised to address it properly.
Why not fix it now? Take a look at the upstream oslo_messaging code and see if/how this was fixed.

It is good to fix this bug. However, this is now a functional change - exceptions that were not being caught would now be handled silently. I'm not comfortable with making this change in stx2.0 - lets put this in once we start work on stx3.0.

Do you think it would be okay if ignore it for now and make a launchpad for this bug? If I don't enable these pylint errors (E0203 and E0202) it is possible for more to be merged into 2.0, which would make it more difficult to pull this change in later. Additionally I don't think I will be around when work starts on 3.0 (I'm going back to school in September).
I spoke to Frank, and he said I should still have time to pull it into 3.0 so this commit can wait as you suggested

Scott, I do like this idea that we "bind" the dependent package lists  with related git repos (similar to the mechanism applied in "centos_iso_image.inc"). 
With this design, one thing we need to is to update the development guide, to remind the developers that they need to clone the *complete source tree* of stx- projects, BEFORE running this "stx-mirror* tool to setup the mirror.

I understand the benefits from the developer perspective to avoid the need to update different repositories when a package needs to be modified (added or deleted).

However, I don't like to enforce the user to clone the entire source in order to create the mirror. I like the idea to be able to run this tool outside the build environment, for example, think in a devops engineering that wants to create a cron job that downloads/updates their regional mirror.

A backward compatibility use case is needed.

- User runs download_mirror.sh.  It prints a warning that the script is depreciated, then calls stx-mirror with possibly remapped arguments to achieve the same effect as the old command.

This will allow a period of backward compatibility. Allowing various build chains time to adapt to the new commands.

I highly recommend that "a yaml file" be changed to "one or more yaml files".  We'd like to reduce the dependencies of other repos on stx-tools.  Long term, I'd like us to have a yaml file in every repo (or every package) which has downloads specific for that repo (or package).

Rather than

  download_dependencies_listed_in('/path/to/something.yaml')

we could have

  for yaml_file in discovered_yaml_files:
    download_dependencies_listed_in(yaml_file)

We don't have to use it like that in the first implementation, but we don't want to limit ourselves to the there-is-a-single-yaml-file behavior in the spec.

In the 3rdparty space we will have CentOS and maybe Debs for same name different version and different format (non-rpm).

Note that the changing of the yaml file content could have the impact of downloading or including unintended code into the product.  (This is the same for .lst files, but I thought I'd mention it).  Currently it is the job of the community, specifically the core of stx-tools, to police the contents of the file and to ensure that any changes are known and expected.

We should explicitly raise the potential of the yaml files to be a vector for inserting unwanted code into the product, and note that caution should be exercised when using them to specify inputs.  Again, this is an argument for separating the yaml into per-repo yaml files, as the subject-matter-experts for each sub-project are in a better position to evaluate and approve package upgrades than the stx-tools core.

    def _is_port_set_binding_supported(self, port, segment):
        """Check if driver is able to bind the port

        Port binding is supported if:
          a. Port VNIC type in supported_vnic_types (currently VNIC_BAREMETAL).
          b. Port is of VNIC type normal and:
            1. bind_normal_ports cfg opt is set.
            2. The segment physnet is in bind_normal_ports_physnets cfg opt.
            3. The device owner is DHCP/Router(Non DVR) related port.

        :param port: port object
        :param segment: Segment dictionary representing the network segment
                        to bind on.
        :return: True if port binding is supported by the driver else False.
        """
        vnic_type = port[portbindings.VNIC_TYPE]

        if vnic_type in self.supported_vnic_types:
            return True

        if (vnic_type == portbindings.VNIC_NORMAL and self.bind_normal_ports
                and port['device_owner'] in self.supported_device_owners and
                segment['physical_network'] in self.bind_normal_ports_physnets):
                return True
        return False

def check_service_client_function(self, function, function2mock,

releasenotes/notes/add-redfish-boot-inte.message: So we're constructing an ISO.... Interesting.  I always kind of thought we would take the path that the other drivers have taken and expect the users to supply a pre-mastered ISO. I guess the plus is we can embed configuration.

Right, I've been contemplating this idea... I can see many benefits doing it this way.   

Off the top of my head:

* Usability: no hassle with re/building ISO version of the images
* Uniformity: from user's perspective, it's the same as with non-virtual media boot methods
* Building UEFI bootable ISOs by hand can be challenging. I mean the machine may not actually like your ISO and hang somewhere along the way.
* Yes, we can hack on the images we build. Perhaps that can be something security or node identity related as well. Not just network configuration. The grub code is already in place for that.
* May be we could extend this design to "local instance boot from virtual media CD"? Meaning that we pull user image + kernel/ramdisk, build ISO, insert it into virtual CD and boot the node. Could be useful for diskless nodes? Keep in mind, that virtual media could also be served over network protocols, not just HTTP pull.

Building just kernel/ramdisk ISOs seems cheap.
nit: "Adds a virtual media boot interface to the ``redfish`` hardware type."

In working through this bug we've discovered (at some expense) that this code is wrong because it doesn't handle instances with user-specified BDMs for local disks, with particularly bad consequences on systems which use predominantly BFV instances. Fixing this shouldn't be very hard, but I appreciate it's not nearly as straightforward as the workaround you've proposed here. However, we don't want to lose the context now we've got it.

  1. All callers of _get_usage_dict need to pass an instance
  2. This code *must* take account of BDMs, and cannot assume that the flavor values are the values actually in use.

The resize logic in this case being which existing disks we're going to resize if the target flavor has a bigger disk than the source flavor. This is its own can of worms, btw.

Yep, agree. I noticed this the first time around but failed to notice it this time.

nova/scheduler/filters/disk_filter.py.message:
I don't like this, because I don't think it solves the problem. It allows us to boot without examining total_usable_disk when we're not using any ephemeral disk. However, if total_usable_disk is less than zero that's a problem. We're just selectively sweeping the problem under the rug for a single edge case.

The issue here is that total_usable_disk is less than zero. Lets try to work out how it got that way, and fix that instead. This means we don't have to add an additional edge case test here, and also it means we can schedule instances which do use ephemeral disk which are currently blocked erroneously by the same invalid total_usable_disk.

This doesn't fix the underlying issue either, but I like this much better because it doesn't special case anything, and it makes it explicit and obvious that we're working around buggy data. This is a more reasonable and comprehensible 'handle obviously wrong data'.

Could you please reference the bug in the comment so when the underlying issue is fixed a future maintainer can confidently remove this?

As you're going to have to touch this again anyway, could you please add something along the lines of:

# This workaround can be removed when bug X is fixed.

nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate..message: Hm, if task.execute() fails, then TargetDBSetupTask wont be in the list of subtasks that needs to be rolled back. But task.execute() can fail after it created already in the target cell database and that needs to be cleaned up.

TargetDBSetupTask will clean up after itself on failure - each subtask has its own rollback, so in the case of TargetDBSetupTask:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/627892/36/nova/conductor/tasks/cross_cell_migrate.py@173

So CrossCellMigrationTask doesn't really need to worry about rolling back that one.

In case it's not clear, each task's execute method is actually wrapping _execute and will trigger a rollback on failure:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/1316c1c2850d2f966f335b628f7f5fe88cef611c/nova/conductor/tasks/base.py#L38

So the _completed_tasks dict is keeping track of successfully completed tasks so that they can be rolled back explicitly if a task *after* them fails, e.g. let's say we do:

* TargetDBSetupTask - ok
* PrepResizeAtDestTask - ok
* PrepResizeAtSourceTask - fails

PrepResizeAtSourceTask will clean itself up because of its own rollback, but CrossCellMigrationTask will be in charge of rolling back PrepResizeAtDestTask and TargetDBSetupTask in reverse order of execution.

paunch/utils/systemctl.py.message:
I think it's not the right place to implement the retries mechanisms.

The main topic of this module is to wrap the systemctl utility.

Systemd can retry things but to do this we need to put some config who look like this:
```
[Unit]
StartLimitInterval=200
StartLimitBurst=5
[Service]
Restart=always
RestartSec=30
```

IMHO these changes and especially the retries mechanisms should be handled here [1] and there [2] by using the `Retrying` class of `tenacity` with something like:

```
retryer = Retrying(
    reraise=True,
    retry=tenacity.retry_if_exception_type(
        SystemctlException
    ),
    wait=tenacity.wait_random_exponential(multiplier=1, max=10),
    stop=tenacity.stop_after_attempt(5))

retryer(systemctl.enable, healthcheck_timer, now=True)
```

This approach allow us to define when a retry is needed and don't force everything to retry.

Also it's more semantical to use the systemd module to handle this instead using the systemctl module.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/paunch/blob/master/paunch/utils/systemd.py#L111
[2] https://github.com/openstack/paunch/blob/master/paunch/utils/systemd.py#L244
Thanks for your feedback, that make sense so ok to leave these changes there.

Thank you for feedback, Herve. I think LimitInterval and Burst settings are something different to the topic, although nice to have as well. This fix allows the locked from starting services to be unlocked back, if that happened so that paunch locked them down mistakenly. Each action that might cause the rate limiting activated and the service blocked, IMO must be wrapped with such a wrapper, which resets fail conters and retries. I see no value in allowing any code invoking that util method w/o such a wrapper, and potentially causing more locking for the services. I think this code should belong here. Alternatively, we could implement a full blown rate limiting for systemctl wrapper to never allow it trigger a blocked state for a service under its control. But I hope the crash-loop performs here good enough and as well.

zuul/executor/server.py.message:
I think we should use utcnow() (and probably include a tz/tz_offset to match), for 2 reasons:
1) Without a tz or offset, it's hard for users to know how to use this time.
2) Because we're actually giving the local time here, and below, we give the UTC time, users who know this can calculate the tz offset and get an approximate location of the server.  That doesn't bother me that much, but it does run counter to one of the stated goals.  At the very least, it does seem a good idea to make executors in different locations behave consistently, so UTC would be a good match here.

I took the behaviour of Ansible, now we are a little different.

I believe it's fine to use UTC (in fact, I think it's better) and expose TZ offset as 0, but I want to raise the fact it's different.

Yes, but omitting the TZ was also different, right?  And, really, the only difference here is that we're forcing the host to be on UTC time whether it is or not.  If the host happened to be configured to keep its local time in UTC, the behavior would be the same.  So I think this is less different than the alternative.  :)

Sorry for my poor wording, I was explaining my agreement, but storing that for the record :)

It seems we are all in agreement.

regarding scope of the verificaction, it does check the three parts mainly:
1. devstack setting for IPv6
2. All deployed services are listening on IPv6
3. run tests cases to verify the internal and external 
communication of that services over IPv6 is proper or not. 
4. This additional verification can be done based on project to project via post-run phase.tcpdump etc or no IPv4 things can be done as part of this but that depends on project to project.
